block.p: Notes of Discord Roger Rees directs the American premiere of ''The Late Middle Class,'' a dark comedy by Simon Gray, at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts. The play, which runs through Aug. 6 on the Nikos Stage, is set in 1950's England and centers on a 12-year-old boy who endures a troublesome relationship with his piano teacher while his parents try to invigorate their drab lives. Information: (413) 597-3399 or www.wtfestival.org.

Tale of the Tape A diverse group of performers will compete for best-video honors when the MTV Video Music Awards are handed out on Sept. 7. Nominees were announced yesterday in 20 categories, including those for rap, rock, rhythm-and-blues and pop. The best-video contenders are Blink 182, for ''All the Small Things''; D'Angelo, ''Untitled (How Does It Feel)''; Eminem, ''The Real Slim Shady''; 'N Sync, ''Bye Bye Bye''; and Red Hot Chili Peppers, ''Californication.'' Nominees for top breakthrough video are Bjork, Blur, the Chemical Brothers, Eminem, 'N Sync and Sisqo. The awards show, at Radio City Music Hall, will be shown live on MTV.

Inspired by Scripture Ancient themes meet modern art in ''Word as Art: Contemporary Renderings,'' an exhibition opening tomorrow at the Gallery of the American Bible Society, 1865 Broadway, at 61st Street. The show of biblical imagery, on view through Oct. 21, presents some 50 works, most made in the last decade using materials like stained glass, photography, assemblage and egg tempera on wood. The pieces were created by 14 artists working in the United States, Israel and South Korea. They include Gene Hoefel, whose mixed-media works retell Bible stories for contemporary viewers; Albinas Elskus, a stained-glass painter; and Dong Hee Suh, who makes ceramic sculptures. Information: (212) 408-1500, or www.americanbible.org.

Breathing With the Ears The violinist Pamela Frank is to be the soloist tonight for the world premiere of Libby Larsen's ''Still Life'' at the opening concert of Bravo! Vail Valley Music Festival in Colorado. Christopher Seaman is to conduct the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, which will perform seven programs, both classical and pop, during the festival, which continues through Aug. 4. The festival commissioned the work by Ms. Larsen, who is its composer in residence this year. She said that in writing the piece she hoped that listeners would ''breathe in and deeply feel the power of the violin to speak freely.'' Information: (877) 827-5700 or www.vailmusicfestival.org
